THEODORE McKELDIN

JHU, Goucher Faculty Members
Urge Disarmament Proposals
More than one hundred members of Johns Hopkins University
and Goucher College faculties
have sent a telegram to Secretary of State Christian Herter,
urging the United States to accept "considerable risk" in an
effort to achieve general disarmame ' at the recently convened
Geneva talks.
The telegram signed by 106
teachers reads in part:
"NEVER HAVE the peoples of
the world spent so much on
armament in time of peace and
never have they been so insecure.
During the past year the arms
competition between the United
States and the Soviet Union has
become more intense than ever.
The continuing spread of nuclear weapons to an enlarging
circle of nations increases the
danger of war and makes disarmament ever more difficult.

DSRC Hearing Procedure
Undergoes Close Scrutiny
A new hearing procedure is
now under consideration by the
DSRC. A report given at the
DSRC meeting Monday, March
14, proposed several changes as
well as a complete amplification of the existing procedures.
The committee of the DSRC
appointed two weeks ago to_ investigate and make recommendations concerning present procedures suggested three major
changes. The first is to have a
two thirds vote necessary to
make a recommendation to the
Dean.
The second basic change in
rules is to have all hearings completely open.
The third basic proposed revision would make any DSRC
member who was in any way
connected with the case in ques-

tion ineligible to sit in the closed
discussion and participate in the
votes of the DSRC.
The new hours for girls in the
dormitory will go into effect this
wekend. This decision was made
at a meeting of all House officers
and Deans Shaffer and Morrill
this Wednesday, March 16.
The hours are as follows:
From 12 noon until 12 midnight
on Friday and Saturday; from
12 noon until 9 p.m. on Sunday.
However, the regulations concerning closing the door will remain status quo with locking of
the door under any condition
being prohibited.
Dean Shaffer also suggested
that the possibility of increasing
facilities for entertaining girls in
the dorms be expanded.

Development Plans For JHU Discussed
At Special Wyman Meeting In Shriver Hall
On Thursday evening, March
10, the University officials met
with a committee from the Wyman Park Association to discuss
the future building plans of
Hopkins.
Melvin J. Sykes, attorney for
the association said the plans
the group received will be given
"very careful study before we
decide whether or not we are
going to fight them."
_ Mr. Allan C. Davis, a member of Hopkins Board of Trustees, said "we are as much interested in preserving the beauty
of this part of the city as anybody in this room."
The Chairman of the meeting, Mr. Davis, pointed out that
the University's most pressing

needs at the moment are for
parking space and athletic fields.
Therefore, we will concentrate
on these two aspects of the expansion in the next five years.

problem."

answered th.at "the parking
problem is greatest by McCoy
students who cannot get here by

this playground (Wyman Park,
west of the University) more
than you. It (intra-mural sports)
is not necessary for a wellrounded college student."

The Interfraternity Council
last Friday approved a report
from its House Committee listing
Greek demands which the University would have to meet in
order to move the fraternities
onto campus.
These demands were as follows:
"The Administration would
not require any chapter to have
a house mother live in the chapter house; the administration
would not require any fraternity
to have chaperons of any type
attend or be responsible for any
social functions of the fraternity;
the administration would not
place any restriction on fraternity parties, fraternity drinking,
or women in chapter houses.
"The Administration would
never put pressure of any type
on the fraternities in total or
any one in particular to pledge
or initiate anyone not meeting
the pledge or initiation requirements of the fraternity in question.
"The Interfraternity Council
of the Johns Hopkins University
shall be solely responsible for the
enforcement of the rules agreed
upon; It shall be the responsibility and obligation of the fraternities to respect and protect
property in the
University
houses.
"A standard design of the
housing facilities would be acceptable, provided each house

by George Bernard Shaw, will be
presented by the Playshop 011
March 31, April 1-3, and Anil'

London suburb in the year 1896.

How to shrink a giant computer
Electronic computers do big jobs-250,000,000 calculations a day, for
instance, in tracking earth satellites.
The computer's already gargantuan capacity is being increased at IBM
as our scientists and engineers probe deep into the mysteries of such
fields as cryogenics, magnetics and microwaves. Utilizing many of their
findings, we are simultaneously working to shrink the giant computers
of today down to Tom Thumb size.
The improvement of our products and methods is an area to which
IBM has devoted a great deal of time and work. This effort has resulted
in a steady, planned growth, which in turn has created excellent career
opportunities for persons of widely diverse skills and talents in research,
engineering, programming and.manufacturing.
A person like yourself, for instance.

The President of the United States, in a news conference Wednesday,. said that there should be "biracial
conferences in e'very city and every community of the
South."
At present groups are actively seeking to organize
students in the colleges and universities in this area for
a city-wide conference to discuss the salient issue of
racial discrimination.
On the Homewood campus it has been repeatedly emphasized that Hopkins, Goucher, and Morgan State studentF,interested in combatting racial bigotry should unite
their efforts.
The adage, "In numbers there is strength," is most
relevant to present circumstances.
If a representative body of the students of this area
would raise enough protest against racial discrimination
in Baltimore, the community would realize that a very
significant segment of the population was sufficiently
aroused against this injustice to do something about it.
Perhaps the local newspapers would then find it too
uncomfortable to continue to play down local efforts to
remove racial barriers, and the "leaders of the community" might be aroused out of their smug complacency
and exert their influence to correct what is aptly described
as a "blight on the community."

When It's Midterm Time .

Unsung Service
Too often the Hopkins Community. is lost in its own
activity of drunken brawls and closed council controversies to even hear about the worthwhile community
projects done by a considerable number of interested and
dedicated men here on campus. We speak in particular
of those who through the Levering Hall YMCA have gone
beyond the limits of the campus and into the city to fill
the voids of public service. Under the direction of Jack
Brown, Assistant Executive Director of the Y, Hopkins
men have taught at the Maryland State Penitentiary,
worked with the children at the Kernan Hospital for
Crippled Children, and visited bed-ridden patients
throughout the city.
To advocate that everyone run out to help little old
ladies across the street is not our aim. We do, however,
wish to recognize the effort of those interested, and to
give them and the YMCA the just recognition they have
earned and deserve..—D.D.

By attaching this committee
to the Student Council directly,
there are several ways in which
the movement might be hampered. If the need arises for immediate action, the committee
may be forced to first refer to
the Council for approvco. This
loss of time could very well
render negotiating sessions ineffectual. At the present time, it
does not appear that the Council
will demand such close rapport
of the committee. But the power
is there none the loss, and one
does not construct a power structure upon the steps that those
presently in power will take. It
is quite possible that the antidiscrimination movement may
have to operate into the next
school year before obtaining results. Next year, there will be a
new Council, and their opinions
concerning the amount of control to be exercised step by step
over the committee in negotiations may change.
If the Council is not going to
control the committee, but will
allow it to act independently,
then there is no reason --at this
committee need now be set up
under the Council. In this light,
the understanding that the committee would eventually become
a separate organizati. n is therefore wholly unnecessary, and in
opinion, the committee
my
should have been set up inde-

pendently right now to guard

long term.
On the other hand, if the
Council is going to control the
committee, it must become fully
informed upon the subject, attend negotiations, etc. It must
do this in order to be qualified
to pass judgement upon the actions of the committee. At the
present time, I do not feel that
the entire Council will do so.
Those of us who are personally,
interested will; those who are
not interested, will not. This is
because working in this movement is really a full time job,
best left to those who started
it as a result of their enthusiasm
and willingness to work. The
committee will doubtless recognize this fact and allow the
founders of the movement to
take a leading role in the negotiations. To me, it appears that
the committee can function well
enough without the burden of an
uninformed Council. If necessary, the Council would be able
to exert its influence by virtue
of the power invested in it by
the Council Constitution whereby
the Countil has authority over
all student activity. With this
legal check in mind, it seems
superfluous to make the committee an integral part of the
Council, and there is a possibility that its efforts may be
hampered.
The committee will serve the
valuable function of concerning
student effort in a drive to end
discrimination. It will in all
probability operate quite well,
and quite effectively. It will serve
as an official organization upon
which responsibility can be
placed for any actions which the
student body disapproves. ..

During his senior year in college, math.
major Kendall T. Murphy had job interviews with several firms, but none of
them appealed to him. "I wasn't interested in doing ptzre mathematics," he
says. "I wanted to apply math and statistics to everyday business problems and
have management responsibilities, too."
At a professor's suggestion, Ken talked
with a Bell System representative and
was "surprised to learn how many practical applications statistics had in telephone company operations." The thorough and varied training program and
opportunities to advance as a member of
management also impressed him.
Ken joined the Pacific Telephone and
Telegraph Company at Sacramento, Cali-

fornia, in June, 1956. Two years of rotational training familiarized him with
company equipment, services and commercial procedures. Then he was assigned to the Chief Statistician's Office
in San Francisco.
Today, as a Staff Statistician, Ken is
applying his math background to a variety of statistical studies dealing with:
rates and revenue, inventory and obsolescence of equipment, customer opinion,
personnel administration, quality control
and auditing.
"This is a big, fast-growing business,"
says Ken,"and I feel I'm helping it operate more efficiently every day. That's a
mighty satisfying way to put my college
education to work."

Ken Murphy got his B.A. in Mathematics from the University of

California's Santa Barbara College in 1956. He's one of many
young men building interesting careers in the Bell Telephone
Companies. Thera could be one for you, too. Be sure to talk
it over with the Bell interviewer when he visits your campus.

This year's Selective Service
Qualification Test for Johns
Hopkins students will be held on
Thursday, April 28, according to
Registrar Irene M. Davis.
Deadline for filing applications
for the test is Thursday, April 7.
All students who have not previously taken this test are eligible to take it this year. The
tests are aimed at providing
students who are not deferred

from the draft by their class
status with the opportunity to
merit deferment via their score
on this test.
"We strongly advise students
here to take the test," Miss Davis
stated, "because at Johns Hopkins the students generally do
very well on this test since the
average level of intelligence is
high."
Students interested may apply
for Bulletins of Information and
test applications at any local
draft board office. The closest
board office to Homewood is at
2024 Maryland Avenue.

More than one hundred members of Johns Hopkins University
and Goucher College faculties
have sent a telegram to Secretary of State Christian Herter,
urging the United States to accept "considerable risk" in an
effort to achieve general disarmame ' at the recently convened
Geneva talks.
The telegram signed by 106
teachers reads in part:
"NEVER HAVE the peoples of
the world spent so much on
armament in time of peace and
never have they been so insecure.
During the past year the arms
competition between the United
States and the Soviet Union has
become more intense than ever.
The continuing spread of nuclear weapons to an enlarging
circle of nations increases the
danger of war and makes disarmament ever more difficult.

DSRC Hearing Procedure
Undergoes Close Scrutiny
A new hearing procedure is
now under consideration by the
DSRC. A report given at the
DSRC meeting Monday, March
14, proposed several changes as
well as a complete amplification of the existing procedures.
The committee of the DSRC
appointed two weeks ago to_ investigate and make recommendations concerning present procedures suggested three major
changes. The first is to have a
two thirds vote necessary to
make a recommendation to the
Dean.
The second basic change in
rules is to have all hearings completely open.
The third basic proposed revision would make any DSRC
member who was in any way
connected with the case in ques-

tion ineligible to sit in the closed
discussion and participate in the
votes of the DSRC.
The new hours for girls in the
dormitory will go into effect this
wekend. This decision was made
at a meeting of all House officers
and Deans Shaffer and Morrill
this Wednesday, March 16.
The hours are as follows:
From 12 noon until 12 midnight
on Friday and Saturday; from
12 noon until 9 p.m. on Sunday.
However, the regulations concerning closing the door will remain status quo with locking of
the door under any condition
being prohibited.
Dean Shaffer also suggested
that the possibility of increasing
facilities for entertaining girls in
the dorms be expanded.

Electronic computers do big jobs-250,000,000 calculations a day, for

fields as cryogenics, magnetics and microwaves. Utilizing many of their

of today down to Tom Thumb size.

IBM has devoted a great deal of time and work. This effort has resulted
in a steady, planned growth, which in turn has created excellent career
opportunities for persons of widely diverse skills and talents in research,

Vieux-Colombier Troupe Presents
'Le Misanthrope' In Comic Vein

The Land of Pleasant Living
The President of the United States, in a news conference Wednesday,. said that there should be "biracial
conferences in e'very city and every community of the
South."
At present groups are actively seeking to organize
students in the colleges and universities in this area for
a city-wide conference to discuss the salient issue of
racial discrimination.
On the Homewood campus it has been repeatedly emphasized that Hopkins, Goucher, and Morgan State studentF,interested in combatting racial bigotry should unite
their efforts.
The adage, "In numbers there is strength," is most
relevant to present circumstances.
If a representative body of the students of this area
would raise enough protest against racial discrimination
in Baltimore, the community would realize that a very
significant segment of the population was sufficiently
aroused against this injustice to do something about it.
Perhaps the local newspapers would then find it too
uncomfortable to continue to play down local efforts to
remove racial barriers, and the "leaders of the community" might be aroused out of their smug complacency
and exert their influence to correct what is aptly described
as a "blight on the community."

When It's Midterm Time .

Unsung Service
Too often the Hopkins Community. is lost in its own
activity of drunken brawls and closed council controversies to even hear about the worthwhile community
projects done by a considerable number of interested and
dedicated men here on campus. We speak in particular
of those who through the Levering Hall YMCA have gone
beyond the limits of the campus and into the city to fill
the voids of public service. Under the direction of Jack
Brown, Assistant Executive Director of the Y, Hopkins
men have taught at the Maryland State Penitentiary,
worked with the children at the Kernan Hospital for
Crippled Children, and visited bed-ridden patients
throughout the city.
To advocate that everyone run out to help little old
ladies across the street is not our aim. We do, however,
wish to recognize the effort of those interested, and to
give them and the YMCA the just recognition they have
earned and deserve..—D.D.

By attaching this committee

the movement might be hampered. If the need arises for immediate action, the committee

the Council for approvco. This

render negotiating sessions ineffectual. At the present time, it

will demand such close rapport
of the committee. But the power
is there none the loss, and one
does not construct a power structure upon the steps that those
presently in power will take. It
is quite possible that the antidiscrimination movement may
have to operate into the next
school year before obtaining results. Next year, there will be a
new Council, and their opinions
concerning the amount of control to be exercised step by step
over the committee in negotiations may change.
If the Council is not going to
control the committee, but will
allow it to act independently,
then there is no reason --at this
committee need now be set up
under the Council. In this light,
the understanding that the committee would eventually become

Those of us who are personally,

YoungDemocrats To Meet—
For Political Orientation
The Johns Hopkins Young
Democrats Club will host a meeting of students from all Maryland colleges tomorrow, March
19, for the purpose of forming
and organizing the Maryland
College Federation of Young
Democratic Clubs.
The conference, to be held
in Levering Hall and slated to
last from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., will
serve to orient the students to
methods of political activity and
organization, according to Fred
Bergerson, president of the club.
The Highlighted features of
the day will include an address
by Carl Tuvin, Executive Sec-

social and a meeting to formulate the plans for the Maryland
Federation.

retary of the State Central Committee and Coordinator of the
Collegiate Young Democrats of
Maryland.
Mrs. George T. Brown, vicechairman for registration of the
Democratic Central Committee
will present a program concerning the various aspects of political action. The presentation will
include a film and a number of
discussion groups led by officials
of the Democratic Party.
The morning session will also
feature a talk on the role of the
college student in American
politics. Following this will be a

Civil Rights
Mr. Phil Camponeshi, Executive Director of the Equal
Opportunities
Employment
Commission of the City of
Baltimore will deliver an address, "Changing Cities and
Civil Rights," today, March
18, at 8:00 p.m. in the Sherwood Room, Levering Hall.

This is the first of a series
of weekly advertisements for
LIFE magazine in which the current issue will be reviewed each
Friday throughout the term.
Even if you don't find your
picture in LIFE, the way Hopkins' own John McIlvain can this
week if he turns to page 114,
you'll still enjoy reading it.
HIGII SOCIETY. McIlvain's
portrait is part of a spread dealing with the closed door of highsociety debutante- parties and
how enterprising young men can
get their foot lodged in it—sort
of a Machiavellian Emily Post
for social climbers. The important thing is that once in, you
must continue to scrounge invitations by means of a soft-sell
technique which includes having
a "conservative" name ("Rockefeller" has a nice restrained ring
to it), learning how to juggle at
least three glasses of champagne while looking supremely
bored with it all and dividing
your dances between hostesses
and wallflowers. With such a
price attached, you may wonder
why anyone would want to attend deb parties in the first
place, but rest assured the whole
expose is fun to read—whether
it provides you with escapism,
rehashed autobiography or training.
CHEESE CAKE! But LIFE
photographs subjects other than
Hopkins students. We see, for
example, a bevy of studious
bathing beauties engaged in a
cheesecake lesson for which I'd
give them an A—but then this is
a test with a different kind of
curve. And in the same vein, the
screen actors' strike catches several stars "in mid movie": Elizabeth Taylor, wrapped in a sheet;
Debbie Reynolds, wrapped
around a bannister; Gina Lollobrigida, wrapped up -in herself,
and Marilyn Monroe, gloriously
unwrapped. Of course there are
other angles to the Hollywood
strike—economics and politics
and such—but they don't photograph as well. Dr. Glass' Biology
1-2 students may find the nature-study pictures of a shiftyeyed chameleon more apropos
and even Biology 1-2 students
being the serious lot they are—
more palatable. Take your pick.
READ? This is only half the
story, though, and if you happen
to read, you'll note with interest
the report on a nationwide survey of what the populace looks

Smashing Serve
Baron is one of the topranked junior players in the
Middle Atlantic area and won
the Maryland Scholastic Association championship while playing at City College. Baron lost
only one match as a frosh and
that was to the number eight
ranked junior in the country.
His smashing serve and powerful game are especially effective
on Homewood's asphalt courts.
Chang has more of a finessegame and is at his peak on clay.
With Baron he forms a versatile
and very effective doubles team.
Stu Cameron is the other sophomore prospect.
Doug Brenner, who was the
top singles player on the team
in his first year of varsity competition, heads the list of four
lettermen returning from last
year's Mason-Dixon championship team. With a year of experience under his belt, Brenner
has overcome some of his un-

during the winter, has held up
fine during practice. Al Freeland and Paul Winegrad are
battling for the crease defense
spot. Phil Sutley, however, looks
good in his first varsity try, but
needs concentrated work to build
up his confidence—he definitely
has the potential to step into a
first-string spot.
Jim Greenwood has the starting goalie position all wrapped
up. Mal Buchner and Bob Baker
are contending for the back-up
job.

During his senior year in college, math.
major Kendall T. Murphy had job interviews with several firms, but none of
them appealed to him. "I wasn't interested in doing ptzre mathematics," he
says. "I wanted to apply math and statistics to everyday business problems and
have management responsibilities, too."
At a professor's suggestion, Ken talked
with a Bell System representative and
was "surprised to learn how many practical applications statistics had in telephone company operations." The thorough and varied training program and
opportunities to advance as a member of
management also impressed him.
Ken joined the Pacific Telephone and
Telegraph Company at Sacramento, Cali-

fornia, in June, 1956. Two years of rotational training familiarized him with
company equipment, services and commercial procedures. Then he was assigned to the Chief Statistician's Office
in San Francisco.
Today, as a Staff Statistician, Ken is
applying his math background to a variety of statistical studies dealing with:
rates and revenue, inventory and obsolescence of equipment, customer opinion,
personnel administration, quality control
and auditing.
"This is a big, fast-growing business,"
says Ken,"and I feel I'm helping it operate more efficiently every day. That's a
mighty satisfying way to put my college
education to work."

Ken Murphy got his B.A. in Mathematics from the University of

California's Santa Barbara College in 1956. He's one of many
young men building interesting careers in the Bell Telephone
Companies. Thera could be one for you, too. Be sure to talk
it over with the Bell interviewer when he visits your campus.

May Take Exam
To Defer Draft
This year's Selective Service
Qualification Test for Johns
Hopkins students will be held on
Thursday, April 28, according to
Registrar Irene M. Davis.
Deadline for filing applications
for the test is Thursday, April 7.
All students who have not previously taken this test are eligible to take it this year. The
tests are aimed at providing
students who are not deferred

from the draft by their class
status with the opportunity to
merit deferment via their score
on this test.
"We strongly advise students
here to take the test," Miss Davis
stated, "because at Johns Hopkins the students generally do
very well on this test since the
average level of intelligence is
high."
Students interested may apply
for Bulletins of Information and
test applications at any local
draft board office. The closest
board office to Homewood is at
2024 Maryland Avenue.
